title: German Rouladen Recipe
description: Bacon, onions and pickles are wrapped in thin slices of flank steak, browned in butter, then simmered in beef broth. Serve with spaetzle to soak up the gravy.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Global Cuisines European German German Rouladen 4.6 (352) 290 Reviews 36 Photos Meat rolls filled with bacon, onions and pickles. Delicious, easy recipe learned while visiting Germany. Submitted by Ron Oldham Updated on November 20, 2024 Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 36 36 36 36 Prep Time: 20 mins Cook Time: 1 hr 10 mins Total Time: 1 hr 30 mins Servings: 6 Yield: 6 servings Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 6 servings 1 ½ pounds flank steak German stone ground mustard, to taste ½ pound thick sliced bacon 2 large onions, sliced 1 (16 ounce) jar dill pickle slices 2 tablespoons butter 2 ½ cups water 1 cube beef bouillon Directions Cut the flank steak into thin filets; about 1/4 inch thick and 3 inches wide. Generously spread one side of each filet with mustard to taste. Place bacon, onions and pickle slices on each filet and form into a roll. Use string or toothpicks to hold the roll together. Heat a skillet over medium heat and melt butter. Place the rolls in the butter and saute until browned. Pour in 2 1/2 cups of water and add the bouillon cube; stirring to dissolve the bouillon cube. Simmer the rolls for about an hour. I Made It Print 491 home cooks made it! Add Your Photo Photos of German Rouladen 01 of 36 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 02 of 36 Photo by  Jake Andersen 06/14/2021 03 of 36 Photo by  Mike Roate 03/01/2020 04 of 36 Photo by  liquidartstattoos 09/14/2019 05 of 36 Photo by  Lisa G 01/06/2019 So, so good! Better than I was expecting, as this was my first attempt at rouladen. Even a picky child ate every bite. Will definitely make this again! 06 of 36 Photo by  Mercedes Folwaczny 12/31/2018 07 of 36 Photo by  Rob Farrell 12/27/2018 08 of 36 Photo by  Tara Dunn 10/24/2018 09 of 36 Photo by  Tara Dunn 10/24/2018 10 of 36 Photo by  Lance Brand 08/29/2018 First time cooking anything German, and it turned out great. I like my food spicy, so I added a little scorpion chili powder and it came out great. 1 2 3 4 Next You’ll Also Love Sous Vide Corned Beef 4 Ratings Easy Sous Vide Corned Beef Mom's Carne Guisada 66 Ratings Easy Slow Cooker Italian Beef 197 Ratings London Broil I 533 Ratings Reuben Pizza 122 Ratings Slow Cooker London Broil 1,012 Ratings Ox Roast 10 Ratings Army SOS Creamed Ground Beef 1,039 Ratings Chicana 78 Ratings Ronaldo's Beef Carnitas 426 Ratings Best Beef Dip Ever 668 Ratings Catherine's Sirloin Tip Roast 102 Ratings Juicy Steak 96 Ratings Easy Bake Brisket 43 Ratings Beef Heart Stew 18 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: Ron Oldham
instructions: Cut the flank steak into thin filets; about 1/4 inch thick and 3 inches wide.;Generously spread one side of each filet with mustard to taste. Place bacon, onions and pickle slices on each filet and form into a roll. Use string or toothpicks to hold the roll together.;Heat a skillet over medium heat and melt butter. Place the rolls in the butter and saute until browned.;Pour in 2 1/2 cups of water and add the bouillon cube; stirring to dissolve the bouillon cube. Simmer the rolls for about an hour.
